exercises.question: The board of directors was forced to back ___ from the proposed merger in light of the sudden market volatility.
exercises.answer: down
exercises.example_sentence: The board of directors was forced to back down from the proposed merger in light of the sudden market volatility.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal inverted sentence regarding a security breach.
exercises.answer: No sooner had the system been breached than the alarm sounded
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had the system been breached than the alarm sounded.

exercises.question: Match the C1 phrasal verbs with their formal definitions.

pairs.right: To reach an agreement after effort

exercises.example_sentence: We need to hammer out the details of the contract before Friday.

exercises.question: Identify the grammatically correct emphatic sentence regarding the CEO's resignation.
options: Not only did the CEO resign, but he also refused to provide a statement.
Not only the CEO resigned, but he also refused to provide a statement.
Not only did the CEO resign, but also he refused to provide a statement.
exercises.answer: Not only did the CEO resign, but he also refused to provide a statement.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did the CEO resign, but he also refused to provide a statement.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following phrase with the correct stress on the negative adverbial: 'Under no circumstances should the data be shared.'
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances should the data be shared.
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should the data be shared.

exercises.question: The legal team decided to hold ___ on the filing until more evidence was gathered.
exercises.answer: off
exercises.example_sentence: The legal team decided to hold off on the filing until more evidence was gathered.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a restrictive condition.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances can we accept liability for damages
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances can we accept liability for damages.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly utilizes 'Seldom' for emphasis?
options: Seldom has such a complex issue been handled with such grace.
Seldom such a complex issue has been handled with such grace.
Seldom such a complex issue was handled with such grace.
exercises.answer: Seldom has such a complex issue been handled with such grace.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom has such a complex issue been handled with such grace.

exercises.question: Match the negative adverbials with their logical sentence completions.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did they know that the market would crash.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal phrase: 'Hardly had the meeting begun when the argument ensued.'
exercises.answer: Hardly had the meeting begun when the argument ensued.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had the meeting begun when the argument ensued.

exercises.question: Notwithstanding the initial setbacks, the project managed to pull ___ at the last minute.
exercises.answer: through
exercises.example_sentence: Notwithstanding the initial setbacks, the project managed to pull through at the last minute.

exercises.question: Choose the correct transformation: 'He had never seen such a beautiful sight.'
options: Never had he seen such a beautiful sight.
Never he had seen such a beautiful sight.
Never he saw such a beautiful sight.
exercises.answer: Never had he seen such a beautiful sight.
exercises.example_sentence: Never had he seen such a beautiful sight.

exercises.question: Reorder the elements to form an 'Only by' inversion.
exercises.answer: Only by working together can we overcome this crisis
exercises.example_sentence: Only by working together can we overcome this crisis.

exercises.question: The CEO's remarks were consistent ___ the company's long-term sustainability goals.
exercises.answer: with
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO's remarks were consistent with the company's long-term sustainability goals.

exercises.question: Connect the advanced verb to its C1 synonym.
exercises.example_sentence: New policies were introduced to curtail unnecessary spending.

exercises.question: Pronounce with focus on the rising intonation for the list: 'Seldom, if ever, have I seen such incompetence.'
exercises.answer: Seldom, if ever, have I seen such incompetence.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom, if ever, have I seen such incompetence.

exercises.question: Select the correct use of 'Not until' in an inverted structure.
options: Not until the results were published did the researchers feel vindicated.
Not until the results were published the researchers felt vindicated.
Not until did the results were published researchers felt vindicated.
exercises.answer: Not until the results were published did the researchers feel vindicated.
exercises.example_sentence: Not until the results were published did the researchers feel vindicated.

exercises.question: Reorder for a negative locative inversion.
exercises.answer: Nowhere else will you find such unspoiled natural beauty
exercises.example_sentence: Nowhere else will you find such unspoiled natural beauty.

exercises.question: Match the 'Only' phrases to their inversion requirements.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after the bell rang did the students leave.

exercises.question: Pronounce this emphatic dismissal: 'In no way does this imply that we are satisfied.'
exercises.answer: In no way does this imply that we are satisfied.
exercises.example_sentence: In no way does this imply that we are satisfied.

exercises.question: Choose the most appropriate mixed conditional to express a past action with a present result.
options: If I had taken that job in London, I would be living there now.
If I took that job in London, I would have been living there now.
If I had taken that job in London, I would have lived there now.
exercises.answer: If I had taken that job in London, I would be living there now.
exercises.example_sentence: If I had taken that job in London, I would be living there now.

exercises.question: Had the committee been more proactive, the current crisis might have been ___ averted.
exercises.answer: entirely
exercises.example_sentence: Had the committee been more proactive, the current crisis might have been entirely averted.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal mixed conditional sentence.
exercises.answer: If he weren't so careless he wouldn't have lost his passport
exercises.example_sentence: If he weren't so careless, he wouldn't have lost his passport.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal hypothetical: 'Were it not for your assistance, we would still be struggling.'
exercises.answer: Were it not for your assistance, we would still be struggling.
exercises.example_sentence: Were it not for your assistance, we would still be struggling.

exercises.question: Match the conditional stems with their logical consequences.

pairs.left: If he hadn't missed the flight

pairs.right: she would have finished by now.
you wouldn't be in this mess.
they would have seen the trap.

exercises.example_sentence: If he hadn't missed the flight, he would be here now.

exercises.question: Identify the correct inversion used to replace 'If' in a hypothetical past context.
options: Had we known about the embargo, we would have adjusted the schedule.
Did we know about the embargo, we would have adjusted the schedule.
Were we known about the embargo, we would have adjusted the schedule.
exercises.answer: Had we known about the embargo, we would have adjusted the schedule.
exercises.example_sentence: Had we known about the embargo, we would have adjusted the schedule.

exercises.question: If the government ___ to implement these changes, the economic outlook would be far brighter today.
exercises.answer: had chosen
exercises.example_sentence: If the government had chosen to implement these changes, the economic outlook would be far brighter today.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a persistent state affecting a past event.
exercises.answer: If I spoke French fluently I would have applied for the job
exercises.example_sentence: If I spoke French fluently, I would have applied for the job.

exercises.question: Pronounce the nuance of regret: 'But for the lack of funding, the project would have succeeded.'
exercises.answer: But for the lack of funding, the project would have succeeded.
exercises.example_sentence: But for the lack of funding, the project would have succeeded.

exercises.question: Match the C1 cohesive devices with their functions in hypothetical speech.

pairs.right: In a way that is appropriate

exercises.example_sentence: Notwithstanding the risks, we proceeded with the investment.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly reflects a mixed conditional using 'Suppose'?
options: Suppose you hadn't found your wallet, what would you be doing now?
Suppose you didn't find your wallet, what would you have done now?
Suppose you hadn't found your wallet, what would you have been doing now?
exercises.answer: Suppose you hadn't found your wallet, what would you be doing now?
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose you hadn't found your wallet, what would you be doing now?

exercises.question: If you weren't so stubborn, you ___ have accepted the apology when it was offered.
exercises.answer: would
exercises.example_sentence: If you weren't so stubborn, you would have accepted the apology when it was offered.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a complex conditional regarding legal compliance.
exercises.answer: Should you require further clarification please contact our legal department
exercises.example_sentence: Should you require further clarification, please contact our legal department.

exercises.question: Match the C1 phrasal verbs to their definitions in a hypothetical context.

pairs.right: To succeed in doing something difficult

exercises.example_sentence: If they hadn't been so organized, they wouldn't have brought off the deal.

exercises.question: Pronounce the conditional using 'if it weren't for': 'If it weren't for the traffic, I would have been home an hour ago.'
exercises.answer: If it weren't for the traffic, I would have been home an hour ago.
exercises.example_sentence: If it weren't for the traffic, I would have been home an hour ago.

exercises.question: We would be enjoying the gala right now if the organizers ___ the event due to the storm.
exercises.answer: hadn't cancelled
exercises.example_sentence: We would be enjoying the gala right now if the organizers hadn't cancelled the event due to the storm.

exercises.question: Select the sentence that best expresses a past regret about a present inability.
options: If I had studied harder at university, I might have a better job today.
If I studied harder at university, I would have a better job today.
If I had studied harder at university, I had a better job today.
exercises.answer: If I had studied harder at university, I might have a better job today.
exercises.example_sentence: If I had studied harder at university, I might have a better job today.

exercises.question: Reorder to describe an unlikely hypothetical present situation.
exercises.answer: If the CEO were to resign the stock price would plummet
exercises.example_sentence: If the CEO were to resign, the stock price would plummet.

exercises.question: Match the hypothetical past phrases with their formal equivalents.

pairs.right: Had it not been for his help

exercises.example_sentence: Had it not been for his help, the project would have failed.

exercises.question: Pronounce the nuanced mixed conditional: 'I wouldn't be so tired if I hadn't stayed up so late.'
exercises.answer: I wouldn't be so tired if I hadn't stayed up so late.
exercises.example_sentence: I wouldn't be so tired if I hadn't stayed up so late.

exercises.question: The CEO is widely reported to ___ been considering a buyout long before the news broke.
exercises.answer: have
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO is widely reported to have been considering a buyout long before the news broke.

exercises.question: Match the reporting verbs with their formal passive patterns.
exercises.example_sentence: He is rumored to be hiding abroad after the scandal.

exercises.question: Identify the most formal way to express that people believe the architect designed the building.
options: The architect is believed to have designed the building.
It is believed the architect to have designed the building.
The architect is believed that he designed the building.
exercises.answer: The architect is believed to have designed the building.
exercises.example_sentence: The architect is believed to have designed the building.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a formal reporting structure regarding archaeological findings.
exercises.answer: The manuscript is understood to date back to the fourteenth century
exercises.example_sentence: The manuscript is understood to date back to the fourteenth century.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following authoritative statement: 'It has been suggested that the policy be reviewed accordingly.'
exercises.answer: It has been suggested that the policy be reviewed accordingly.
exercises.example_sentence: It has been suggested that the policy be reviewed accordingly.

exercises.question: The minister was made ___ resign following the disclosure of the classified documents.
exercises.answer: to
exercises.example_sentence: The minister was made to resign following the disclosure of the classified documents.

exercises.question: Choose the correct causative structure for a high-level professional context.
options: The firm had the contract scrutinized by a team of legal experts.
The firm got the contract scrutinize by a team of legal experts.
The firm had scrutinize the contract by a team of legal experts.
exercises.answer: The firm had the contract scrutinized by a team of legal experts.
exercises.example_sentence: The firm had the contract scrutinized by a team of legal experts.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to describe a suspected criminal activity.
exercises.answer: He is reputed to be the mastermind behind the entire operation
exercises.example_sentence: He is reputed to be the mastermind behind the entire operation.

exercises.question: Match the C1 causative/passive phrasal verbs with their meanings.

pairs.right: To act strictly to stop something

exercises.example_sentence: Large portions of the budget were being siphoned off into private accounts.

exercises.question: Pronounce with neutral reporting intonation: 'There are estimated to be thousands of undiscovered species.'
exercises.answer: There are estimated to be thousands of undiscovered species.
exercises.example_sentence: There are estimated to be thousands of undiscovered species.

exercises.question: The suspect is believed to ___ fleeing the country when the authorities intervened.
exercises.answer: have been
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect is believed to have been fleeing the country when the authorities intervened.

exercises.question: Identify the error-free sentence regarding public perception.
options: The new legislation is considered to be a major step forward.
The new legislation is considered as a major step forward.
The new legislation considers to be a major step forward.
exercises.answer: The new legislation is considered to be a major step forward.
exercises.example_sentence: The new legislation is considered to be a major step forward.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a causative sentence about maintenance.
exercises.answer: We must get the ventilation system upgraded before the summer begins
exercises.example_sentence: We must get the ventilation system upgraded before the summer begins.

exercises.question: Match the advanced synonyms for reporting verbs.
exercises.example_sentence: Critics contend that the data was manipulated.

exercises.question: Pronounce this formal disclaimer: 'The views expressed are not to be taken as legal advice.'
exercises.answer: The views expressed are not to be taken as legal advice.
exercises.example_sentence: The views expressed are not to be taken as legal advice.

exercises.question: It is ___ that the two companies have been in secret talks for months.
exercises.answer: contended
exercises.example_sentence: It is contended that the two companies have been in secret talks for months.

exercises.question: Select the correct passive form of a verb that usually takes two objects.
options: He was awarded a prestigious scholarship for his research.
A prestigious scholarship was awarded him for his research.
He was awarded to a prestigious scholarship for his research.
exercises.answer: He was awarded a prestigious scholarship for his research.
exercises.example_sentence: He was awarded a prestigious scholarship for his research.

exercises.question: Reorder to express a passive requirement.
exercises.answer: The regulations are to be strictly adhered to notwithstanding any prior agreements
exercises.example_sentence: The regulations are to be strictly adhered to notwithstanding any prior agreements.

exercises.question: Match the active sentence to its formal passive counterpart.

pairs.left: People claim he is a genius.
pairs.right: He is claimed to be a genius.

pairs.left: Experts believe it was a fluke.
pairs.right: It is believed to have been a fluke.
She is thought to have left.

exercises.example_sentence: It is believed to have been a fluke, contrary to popular opinion.

exercises.question: Pronounce this formal causative: 'I need to have my visa extended before the deadline.'
exercises.answer: I need to have my visa extended before the deadline.
exercises.example_sentence: I need to have my visa extended before the deadline.

exercises.question: Select the correct cleft sentence to emphasize the reason for the project's failure.
options: What led to the project's failure was the lack of clear communication.
It was the lack of clear communication what led to the project's failure.
The thing what led to the project's failure was the lack of clear communication.
exercises.answer: What led to the project's failure was the lack of clear communication.
exercises.example_sentence: What led to the project's failure was the lack of clear communication.

exercises.question: The negotiations reached a stalemate, ___ point the mediator intervened to suggest a compromise.
exercises.answer: at which
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations reached a stalemate, at which point the mediator intervened to suggest a compromise.

exercises.question: Match the C1 relative structures to their formal equivalents.

pairs.left: The person to whom I spoke
The manner in which it was done
The reason for which he left

exercises.example_sentence: The manner in which it was done was entirely unprofessional.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal cleft sentence emphasizing the CEO's vision.
exercises.answer: It is the CEO's visionary leadership that has driven our recent success
exercises.example_sentence: It is the CEO's visionary leadership that has driven our recent success.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following emphatic sentence: 'What I find most intriguing is the sheer complexity of the data.'
exercises.answer: What I find most intriguing is the sheer complexity of the data.
exercises.example_sentence: What I find most intriguing is the sheer complexity of the data.

exercises.question: The company, ___ headquarters are based in Zurich, is expanding its operations to Southeast Asia.
exercises.answer: whose
exercises.example_sentence: The company, whose headquarters are based in Zurich, is expanding its operations to Southeast Asia.

exercises.question: Identify the grammatically correct sentence involving a 'quantifier + of + whom/which' structure.
options: There were several proposals, most of which were deemed impractical.
There were several proposals, most of them were deemed impractical.
There were several proposals, which most of were deemed impractical.
exercises.answer: There were several proposals, most of which were deemed impractical.
exercises.example_sentence: There were several proposals, most of which were deemed impractical.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a formal relative clause.
exercises.answer: This is a circumstance in which extraordinary measures must be taken
exercises.example_sentence: This is a circumstance in which extraordinary measures must be taken.

exercises.question: Match the C1 adverbs of manner with their sophisticated synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The data was meticulously organized by the research team.

exercises.question: Pronounce with focus on the cleft structure: 'It wasn't until midnight that the final votes were tallied.'
exercises.answer: It wasn't until midnight that the final votes were tallied.
exercises.example_sentence: It wasn't until midnight that the final votes were tallied.

exercises.question: The software, the development ___ took nearly three years, has finally been released.
exercises.answer: of which
exercises.example_sentence: The software, the development of which took nearly three years, has finally been released.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses a cleft structure to emphasize the 'where' element?
options: It was in the heart of the city that the protest took place.
The heart of the city was where the protest took place.
Where the protest took place was the heart of the city.
exercises.answer: It was in the heart of the city that the protest took place.
exercises.example_sentence: It was in the heart of the city that the protest took place.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a result using a relative pronoun.
exercises.answer: He arrived late for the interview which was unfortunate to say the least
exercises.example_sentence: He arrived late for the interview, which was unfortunate to say the least.

exercises.question: Match the relative clause type to its specific function.
exercises.example_sentence: He lost his keys, which really annoyed him.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following formal relative clause: 'The candidate with whom you interviewed has been shortlisted.'
exercises.answer: The candidate with whom you interviewed has been shortlisted.
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate with whom you interviewed has been shortlisted.

exercises.question: The resolution, ___ the board had been working for months, was finally adopted.
exercises.answer: on which
exercises.example_sentence: The resolution, on which the board had been working for months, was finally adopted.

exercises.question: Choose the most sophisticated sentence using an 'all-cleft'.
options: All I want is a clear explanation of the budget discrepancies.
All what I want is a clear explanation of the budget discrepancies.
Everything what I want is a clear explanation of the budget discrepancies.
exercises.answer: All I want is a clear explanation of the budget discrepancies.
exercises.example_sentence: All I want is a clear explanation of the budget discrepancies.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a cleft sentence that focuses on time.
exercises.answer: It was only after the audit that the errors came to light
exercises.example_sentence: It was only after the audit that the errors came to light.

exercises.question: Match the C1 phrasal verbs related to communication with their definitions.
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO had to spell out the new strategy for the employees.

exercises.question: Pronounce the sentential relative clause: 'The stock prices plummeted, which caused widespread panic.'
exercises.answer: The stock prices plummeted, which caused widespread panic.
exercises.example_sentence: The stock prices plummeted, which caused widespread panic.

exercises.question: Choose the most sophisticated way to express strong past probability regarding a missing document.
options: The secretary might well have overlooked the file during the transition.
The secretary must have been overlooking the file during the transition.
The secretary can't have overlooked the file during the transition.
exercises.answer: The secretary might well have overlooked the file during the transition.
exercises.example_sentence: The secretary might well have overlooked the file during the transition.

exercises.question: The expansion was successful, ___ somewhat costly in terms of human resources.
exercises.answer: albeit
exercises.example_sentence: The expansion was successful, albeit somewhat costly in terms of human resources.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a concessive sentence expressing strong dislike.
exercises.answer: Much as I dislike the proposal I must acknowledge its merit
exercises.example_sentence: Much as I dislike the proposal, I must acknowledge its merit.

exercises.question: Match the modal phrases to their intended level of certainty.
exercises.example_sentence: He can't have been serious about resigning so soon.

exercises.question: Pronounce the deduction with the correct emphatic stress: 'He couldn't possibly have known about the merger.'
exercises.answer: He couldn't possibly have known about the merger.
exercises.example_sentence: He couldn't possibly have known about the merger.

exercises.question: Given his track record, he ___ to have reached the target by the end of the quarter.
exercises.answer: ought
exercises.example_sentence: Given his track record, he ought to have reached the target by the end of the quarter.

exercises.question: Select the sentence that correctly expresses a concessive relationship using 'However'.
options: However hard they tried, they couldn't secure the venture capital.
Hardly however they tried, they couldn't secure the venture capital.
However they tried hard, they couldn't secure the venture capital.
exercises.answer: However hard they tried, they couldn't secure the venture capital.
exercises.example_sentence: However hard they tried, they couldn't secure the venture capital.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past deduction about an event.
exercises.answer: The theft must have taken place under the cover of darkness
exercises.example_sentence: The theft must have taken place under the cover of darkness.

exercises.question: Match the C1 phrasal verbs with their synonyms in context of deduction.
exercises.example_sentence: The investigators are trying to piece together the evidence.

exercises.question: Pronounce the concession: 'Even so, we cannot ignore the long-term implications.'
exercises.answer: Even so, we cannot ignore the long-term implications.
exercises.example_sentence: Even so, we cannot ignore the long-term implications.

exercises.question: You ___ have told me you were bringing guests; I would have prepared more food.
exercises.answer: might
exercises.example_sentence: You might have told me you were bringing guests; I would have prepared more food.

exercises.question: Choose the correct structure for a past 'was supposed to' context.
options: The shipment was to have arrived yesterday, but it was delayed.
The shipment was have arrived yesterday, but it was delayed.
The shipment was to arrived yesterday, but it was delayed.
exercises.answer: The shipment was to have arrived yesterday, but it was delayed.
exercises.example_sentence: The shipment was to have arrived yesterday, but it was delayed.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a sentence expressing the impossibility of a past event.
exercises.answer: He can't have stolen the money as he was with us
exercises.example_sentence: He can't have stolen the money as he was with us.

exercises.question: Match the C1 connectors with their logic.

pairs.left: In spite of the fact that

exercises.example_sentence: In spite of the fact that it was raining, the event continued.

exercises.question: Pronounce with focus on speculation: 'The perpetrator may well have fled the country by now.'
exercises.answer: The perpetrator may well have fled the country by now.
exercises.example_sentence: The perpetrator may well have fled the country by now.

exercises.question: ___ the risks involved, the surgeon decided to proceed with the operation.
exercises.answer: Notwithstanding
exercises.example_sentence: Notwithstanding the risks involved, the surgeon decided to proceed with the operation.

exercises.question: Identify the correct way to express a past probability that didn't happen.
options: I could have gone to the party, but I was too tired.
I must have gone to the party, but I was too tired.
I should go to the party, but I was too tired.
exercises.answer: I could have gone to the party, but I was too tired.
exercises.example_sentence: I could have gone to the party, but I was too tired.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal sentence using 'albeit'.
exercises.answer: The negotiations were successful albeit extremely drawn out and exhausting
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations were successful, albeit extremely drawn out and exhausting.

exercises.question: Match the modal 'should have' uses with the speaker's intent.
exercises.example_sentence: You should have seen the look on his face!

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex concession: 'Hard as they tried, the researchers could not replicate the results.'
exercises.answer: Hard as they tried, the researchers could not replicate the results.
exercises.example_sentence: Hard as they tried, the researchers could not replicate the results.

exercises.question: The committee recommended that the proposal ___ rejected on the grounds of insufficient data.
exercises.answer: be
exercises.example_sentence: The committee recommended that the proposal be rejected on the grounds of insufficient data.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses the unreal past to express a present preference regarding someone else's behavior?
options: I would rather you didn't disclose the confidential information yet.
I would rather you don't disclose the confidential information yet.
I would rather you haven't disclosed the confidential information yet.
exercises.answer: I would rather you didn't disclose the confidential information yet.
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather you didn't disclose the confidential information yet.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal sentence using nominalization for a more academic tone.
exercises.answer: The sudden resignation of the chairman led to widespread instability
exercises.example_sentence: The sudden resignation of the chairman led to widespread instability.

exercises.question: Match the subjunctive triggers with their formal completions.

pairs.right: she take a leave of absence.

exercises.example_sentence: It is essential that he arrive on time for the hearing.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following emphatic wish: 'If only I hadn't squandered the opportunity when I had the chance!'
exercises.answer: If only I hadn't squandered the opportunity when I had the chance!
exercises.example_sentence: If only I hadn't squandered the opportunity when I had the chance!

exercises.question: Identify the correct structure for expressing an urgent requirement.
options: It is imperative that every employee remain vigilant during the transition.
It is imperative that every employee remains vigilant during the transition.
It is imperative that every employee remained vigilant during the transition.
exercises.answer: It is imperative that every employee remain vigilant during the transition.
exercises.example_sentence: It is imperative that every employee remain vigilant during the transition.

exercises.question: It's high time the government ___ the issue of rising inflation more seriously.
exercises.answer: addressed
exercises.example_sentence: It's high time the government addressed the issue of rising inflation more seriously.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past regret using 'wish'.
exercises.answer: I wish I had been made aware of the potential consequences
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I had been made aware of the potential consequences.

exercises.question: Match the nominalized phrases with their verb-based equivalents.
exercises.example_sentence: The reduction of costs is paramount to our survival.

exercises.question: Pronounce with formal intonation: 'Long live the spirit of innovation that drives this company.'
exercises.answer: Long live the spirit of innovation that drives this company.
exercises.example_sentence: Long live the spirit of innovation that drives this company.

exercises.question: Had it not been for the ___ of the manager, the conflict would have escalated.
exercises.answer: intervention
exercises.example_sentence: Had it not been for the intervention of the manager, the conflict would have escalated.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase to complete this formal request: 'It is requested that the meeting ___.'
exercises.answer: be adjourned until Monday.
exercises.example_sentence: It is requested that the meeting be adjourned until Monday.

exercises.question: Reorder to form a sentence expressing a hypothetical present.
exercises.answer: Suppose you were offered the position would you be willing to relocate
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose you were offered the position; would you be willing to relocate?

exercises.question: Match the C1 idioms to their definitions in a formal context.
exercises.example_sentence: We need to ensure all procedures are done by the book.

exercises.question: Pronounce this formal preference: 'I would sooner you had consulted me before making that decision.'
exercises.answer: I would sooner you had consulted me before making that decision.
exercises.example_sentence: I would sooner you had consulted me before making that decision.

exercises.question: The ___ of the new policy was met with significant resistance from the staff.
exercises.answer: implementation
exercises.example_sentence: The implementation of the new policy was met with significant resistance from the staff.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'lest' for a formal warning.
options: We must be cautious lest we offend our potential investors.
We must be cautious lest we will offend our potential investors.
We must be cautious lest we offending our potential investors.
exercises.answer: We must be cautious lest we offend our potential investors.
exercises.example_sentence: We must be cautious lest we offend our potential investors.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing a past 'as if' scenario.
exercises.answer: He spoke about the crisis as if he had personally witnessed it
exercises.example_sentence: He spoke about the crisis as if he had personally witnessed it.

exercises.question: Match the C1 cohesive devices with their formal synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: They acted by virtue of the powers granted to them.

exercises.question: Pronounce this formal subjunctive: 'Suffice it to say, the project did not meet its objectives.'
exercises.answer: Suffice it to say, the project did not meet its objectives.
exercises.example_sentence: Suffice it to say, the project did not meet its objectives.

exercises.question: The CEO's profound insight ___ the market trends allowed the firm to pivot successfully.
exercises.answer: into
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO's profound insight into the market trends allowed the firm to pivot successfully.

exercises.question: Match the C1 nouns with their mandatory dependent prepositions.
exercises.example_sentence: The new safety regulations take precedence over the old ones.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a perfect participial phrase.
exercises.answer: Having already secured the funding the team commenced the initial research
exercises.example_sentence: Having already secured the funding, the team commenced the initial research.

exercises.question: Identify the correct reduction of the following relative clause: 'The building, which was designed by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.'
options: The building, designed by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.
The building, designing by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.
The building, having designed by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.
exercises.answer: The building, designed by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.
exercises.example_sentence: The building, designed by a world-renowned architect, is a landmark.

exercises.question: Pronounce the participial phrase with correct prosody: 'Not wanting to cause any further distress, the journalist withheld the names.'
exercises.answer: Not wanting to cause any further distress, the journalist withheld the names.
exercises.example_sentence: Not wanting to cause any further distress, the journalist withheld the names.

exercises.question: ___ by the positive feedback, the developer decided to release an early beta version.
exercises.answer: Encouraged
exercises.example_sentence: Encouraged by the positive feedback, the developer decided to release an early beta version.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence involving a 'dangling participle' error correction.
options: Running down the street, my hat blew off.
Running down the street, I lost my hat.
While running down the street, the wind took my hat.
exercises.answer: Running down the street, I lost my hat.
exercises.example_sentence: Running down the street, I lost my hat.

exercises.question: Match the verbs with the correct participial structure.
exercises.example_sentence: I found the document hidden in the desk among several other files.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal sentence with a causative-participial mix.
exercises.answer: With the work finished early the staff were permitted to leave
exercises.example_sentence: With the work finished early, the staff were permitted to leave.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for clarity: 'Having been warned of the risks, he proceeded with extreme caution.'
exercises.answer: Having been warned of the risks, he proceeded with extreme caution.
exercises.example_sentence: Having been warned of the risks, he proceeded with extreme caution.

exercises.question: There is a significant lack of consensus regarding the proposed changes ___ the tax code.
exercises.answer: to
exercises.example_sentence: There is a significant lack of consensus regarding the proposed changes to the tax code.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses an 'ing-form' as a sentence connector?
options: Regarding the new policy, we have some reservations.
Regard the new policy, we have some reservations.
Regardless the new policy, we have some reservations.
exercises.answer: Regarding the new policy, we have some reservations.
exercises.example_sentence: Regarding the new policy, we have some reservations.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing simultaneous actions.
exercises.answer: Listening to the evidence the judge noted several major discrepancies
exercises.example_sentence: Listening to the evidence, the judge noted several major discrepancies.

exercises.question: Match the C1 sophisticated words to their contextual definitions.
exercises.example_sentence: There was no discernible improvement in the patient's condition.

exercises.question: Pronounce the participial reduction: 'The individuals involved in the dispute refused to comment.'
exercises.answer: The individuals involved in the dispute refused to comment.
exercises.example_sentence: The individuals involved in the dispute refused to comment.

exercises.question: Her dedication ___ environmental preservation has earned her numerous accolades.
exercises.answer: to
exercises.example_sentence: Her dedication to environmental preservation has earned her numerous accolades.

exercises.question: Identify the correct structure using 'Having' + past participle.
options: Having finished her degree, she embarked on a world tour.
Having finish her degree, she embarked on a world tour.
Having finishing her degree, she embarked on a world tour.
exercises.answer: Having finished her degree, she embarked on a world tour.
exercises.example_sentence: Having finished her degree, she embarked on a world tour.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal sentence with a passive participial phrase.
exercises.answer: Built on a foundation of trust the partnership has endured decades
exercises.example_sentence: Built on a foundation of trust, the partnership has endured decades.

exercises.question: Match the prepositional phrases with their C1 meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: In the wake of the scandal, the CEO resigned immediately.

exercises.question: Pronounce the sentence involving a noun-preposition pair: 'We had to take into account his vulnerability to criticism.'
exercises.answer: We had to take into account his vulnerability to criticism.
exercises.example_sentence: We had to take into account his vulnerability to criticism.

exercises.question: The government attempted to ___ down the severity of the economic downturn to avoid widespread panic.
exercises.answer: play
exercises.example_sentence: The government attempted to play down the severity of the economic downturn to avoid widespread panic.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using fronting for dramatic effect.
exercises.answer: At no point during the negotiations did the management consider conceding
exercises.example_sentence: At no point during the negotiations did the management consider conceding.

exercises.question: Match the C1 phrasal verbs to their formal definitions.
exercises.example_sentence: The central bank acted quickly to shore up the national currency.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following inverted sentence: 'Only after months of deliberation was a verdict finally reached.'
exercises.answer: Only after months of deliberation was a verdict finally reached.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after months of deliberation was a verdict finally reached.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of fronting to emphasize a location.
options: In the middle of the valley stood an ancient, crumbling fortress.
An ancient, crumbling fortress stood in the middle of the valley.
In the middle of the valley did an ancient fortress stand.
exercises.answer: In the middle of the valley stood an ancient, crumbling fortress.
exercises.example_sentence: In the middle of the valley stood an ancient, crumbling fortress.

exercises.question: The authorities have decided to ___ down on illegal street racing following a series of accidents.
exercises.answer: clamp
exercises.example_sentence: The authorities have decided to clamp down on illegal street racing following a series of accidents.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal sentence using 'Hardly'.
exercises.answer: Hardly had the investors signed the agreement when the market collapsed
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had the investors signed the agreement when the market collapsed.

exercises.question: Match the emphatic structures to their grammatical categories.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom have I witnessed such a display of utter incompetence.

exercises.question: Select the correct transformation of 'He didn't realize his mistake until much later.'
options: Not until much later did he realize his mistake.
Not until much later he realized his mistake.
Not until much later he did realize his mistake.
exercises.answer: Not until much later did he realize his mistake.
exercises.example_sentence: Not until much later did he realize his mistake.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic fronted adjective: 'Try as they might, they could not bypass the security protocols.'
exercises.answer: Try as they might, they could not bypass the security protocols.
exercises.example_sentence: Try as they might, they could not bypass the security protocols.

exercises.question: Scarcely had the resolution been passed ___ the opposition filed a legal challenge.
exercises.answer: when
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had the resolution been passed when the opposition filed a legal challenge.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence emphasizing a condition.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances should you divulge the encryption keys to unauthorized personnel
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should you divulge the encryption keys to unauthorized personnel.

exercises.question: Match the 'up' phrasal verbs with their C1 level usage.
exercises.example_sentence: The consultant took a moment to size up the competition.

exercises.question: Identify the correct way to front a 'bare' infinitive for emphasis.
options: Win the championship they did, but not without significant controversy.
To win the championship they did, but not without significant controversy.
Winning the championship they did, but not without significant controversy.
exercises.answer: Win the championship they did, but not without significant controversy.
exercises.example_sentence: Win the championship they did, but not without significant controversy.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for rhetorical effect: 'So intense was the heat that the tarmac began to melt.'
exercises.answer: So intense was the heat that the tarmac began to melt.
exercises.example_sentence: So intense was the heat that the tarmac began to melt.

exercises.question: Rarely ___ such a sophisticated piece of malware been detected in a civilian network.
exercises.answer: has
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely has such a sophisticated piece of malware been detected in a civilian network.

exercises.question: Reorder for a sentence describing a sudden appearance.
exercises.answer: Out of the shadows stepped a figure shrouded in mystery
exercises.example_sentence: Out of the shadows stepped a figure shrouded in mystery.

exercises.question: Match the adverbial phrase to the correct inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did she suspect that her life was about to change.

exercises.question: Which of these expresses the idea that 'they succeeded despite the odds' using an emphatic structure?
options: Succeed they did, against all expectations.
Succeed did they, against all expectations.
To succeed they did, against all expectations.
exercises.answer: Succeed they did, against all expectations.
exercises.example_sentence: Succeed they did, against all expectations.

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex negative adverbial: 'No sooner had the ink dried than the terms were contested.'
exercises.answer: No sooner had the ink dried than the terms were contested.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had the ink dried than the terms were contested.

exercises.question: The scientific community is on the ___ of a major breakthrough regarding quantum computing.
exercises.answer: verge
exercises.example_sentence: The scientific community is on the verge of a major breakthrough regarding quantum computing.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal sentence about a scheduled event.
exercises.answer: The summit is due to commence at ten sharp tomorrow morning
exercises.example_sentence: The summit is due to commence at ten sharp tomorrow morning.

exercises.question: Choose the correct quantifier for emphasizing a total lack of something in a formal context.
options: The audit revealed no discrepancies whatsoever in the financial records.
The audit revealed no discrepancies whatever in the financial records.
The audit revealed no discrepancies at all whatever in the financial records.
exercises.answer: The audit revealed no discrepancies whatsoever in the financial records.
exercises.example_sentence: The audit revealed no discrepancies whatsoever in the financial records.

exercises.question: Match the C1 future structures with their intended meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: Interest rates are set to rise again in the next quarter.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for emphasis: 'Each and every member of the staff must attend the briefing.'
exercises.answer: Each and every member of the staff must attend the briefing.
exercises.example_sentence: Each and every member of the staff must attend the briefing.

exercises.question: The negotiations are ___ to fail unless both parties show more flexibility.
exercises.answer: bound
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations are bound to fail unless both parties show more flexibility.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'all too' to express a negative frequency.
options: It is all too common for small businesses to struggle in their first year.
It is too all common for small businesses to struggle in their first year.
Small businesses struggle all too commonly in their first year.
exercises.answer: It is all too common for small businesses to struggle in their first year.
exercises.example_sentence: It is all too common for small businesses to struggle in their first year.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express an immediate future action.
exercises.answer: The minister was on the point of resigning when the news broke
exercises.example_sentence: The minister was on the point of resigning when the news broke.

exercises.question: Match the C1 distributives with their grammatical rules.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither candidate was deemed suitable for the executive role.

exercises.question: Pronounce the speculative future: 'The company might well be acquired by a larger conglomerate.'
exercises.answer: The company might well be acquired by a larger conglomerate.
exercises.example_sentence: The company might well be acquired by a larger conglomerate.

exercises.question: The proposed tax reforms have met with ___ resistance from the manufacturing sector.
exercises.answer: considerable
exercises.example_sentence: The proposed tax reforms have met with considerable resistance from the manufacturing sector.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'all the' for emphasis with a superlative?
options: The victory was all the more impressive given the team's injuries.
The victory was all impressive more given the team's injuries.
The victory was all more the impressive given the team's injuries.
exercises.answer: The victory was all the more impressive given the team's injuries.
exercises.example_sentence: The victory was all the more impressive given the team's injuries.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a destiny-related future.
exercises.answer: They were fated never to meet again after that fateful summer
exercises.example_sentence: They were fated never to meet again after that fateful summer.

exercises.question: Match the quantifiers to the level of formality/intensity.
exercises.example_sentence: An overwhelming majority of shareholders voted in favor of the merger.

exercises.question: Pronounce the determiner focus: 'Little did they know that neither option was viable.'
exercises.answer: Little did they know that neither option was viable.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did they know that neither option was viable.

exercises.question: The project is on the ___ of completion, with only minor details remaining.
exercises.answer: brink
exercises.hint: Often used for disaster or success
exercises.example_sentence: The project is on the brink of completion, with only minor details remaining.

exercises.question: Identify the correct distributive use in a formal negative sentence.
options: Neither of the witnesses was able to provide a clear description.
None of the two witnesses was able to provide a clear description.
Both of the witnesses was not able to provide a clear description.
exercises.answer: Neither of the witnesses was able to provide a clear description.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither of the witnesses was able to provide a clear description.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express an unlikely but possible future.
exercises.answer: If the deal were to go through it would revolutionize the industry
exercises.example_sentence: If the deal were to go through, it would revolutionize the industry.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words with their nuanced synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The evidence provided was deemed sufficient to proceed with the trial.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic distributive: 'Every single discrepancy must be accounted for by the end of the day.'
exercises.answer: Every single discrepancy must be accounted for by the end of the day.
exercises.example_sentence: Every single discrepancy must be accounted for by the end of the day.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a negative inversion for emphasis?
options: Seldom have I witnessed such a remarkable display of talent.
Seldom I have witnessed such a remarkable display of talent.
Seldom did I witnessed such a remarkable display of talent.
exercises.answer: Seldom have I witnessed such a remarkable display of talent.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom have I witnessed such a remarkable display of talent.

exercises.question: The board of directors took ___ to the claims that the company had intentionally misled investors.
exercises.answer: exception
exercises.example_sentence: The board of directors took exception to the claims that the company had intentionally misled investors.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal mandative subjunctive sentence.
exercises.answer: It is imperative that the chairman be informed of the audit results
exercises.hint: Use the base form of the verb
exercises.example_sentence: It is imperative that the chairman be informed of the audit results.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verbs to their formal synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: All members must abide by the updated code of conduct.

exercises.question: Pronounce the conditional inversion: 'Had we known about the technical limitations, we would have adjusted the timeline.'
exercises.answer: Had we known about the technical limitations, we would have adjusted the timeline.
exercises.example_sentence: Had we known about the technical limitations, we would have adjusted the timeline.

exercises.question: The candidate's argument was ___ on the assumption that the economy would continue to grow.
exercises.answer: predicated
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate's argument was predicated on the assumption that the economy would continue to grow.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'were' in a formal hypothetical statement.
options: Were the government to raise taxes, consumer spending would likely fall.
Were the government raise taxes, consumer spending would likely fall.
Was the government to raise taxes, consumer spending would likely fall.
exercises.answer: Were the government to raise taxes, consumer spending would likely fall.
exercises.example_sentence: Were the government to raise taxes, consumer spending would likely fall.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence emphasizing a rare occurrence.
exercises.answer: Scarcely had the announcement been made when the protests began
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had the announcement been made when the protests began.

exercises.question: Match the idioms to their definitions.
exercises.example_sentence: He gave the speech off the cuff, yet it was remarkably persuasive.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for emphasis: 'Not only was the service poor, but the food was also overpriced.'
exercises.answer: Not only was the service poor, but the food was also overpriced.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only was the service poor, but the food was also overpriced.

exercises.question: The CEO decided to ___ down from his position to focus on personal philanthropic projects.
exercises.answer: step
exercises.example_sentence: The CEO decided to step down from his position to focus on personal philanthropic projects.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a participial phrase to provide a reason?
options: Fearing a backlash, the committee decided to postpone the vote.
Feared a backlash, the committee decided to postpone the vote.
Having fearing a backlash, the committee decided to postpone the vote.
exercises.answer: Fearing a backlash, the committee decided to postpone the vote.
exercises.example_sentence: Fearing a backlash, the committee decided to postpone the vote.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past preference.
exercises.answer: I would sooner you had not disclosed those details to the press
exercises.example_sentence: I would sooner you had not disclosed those details to the press.

exercises.question: Match the reporting verbs with their corresponding meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: The lawyer attempted to refute the evidence presented by the prosecution.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic sentence: 'What I find most concerning is the lack of transparency.'
exercises.answer: What I find most concerning is the lack of transparency.
exercises.example_sentence: What I find most concerning is the lack of transparency.

exercises.question: The negotiations were successful, ___ somewhat more difficult than we had anticipated.
exercises.answer: albeit
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations were successful, albeit somewhat more difficult than we had anticipated.

exercises.question: Identify the correct preposition for the following noun.
options: The scientist's insight into the genetic code was revolutionary.
The scientist's insight for the genetic code was revolutionary.
The scientist's insight on the genetic code was revolutionary.
exercises.answer: The scientist's insight into the genetic code was revolutionary.
exercises.example_sentence: The scientist's insight into the genetic code was revolutionary.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a possessive relative clause.
exercises.answer: The company whose profits have doubled this year is planning an IPO
exercises.example_sentence: The company whose profits have doubled this year is planning an IPO.

exercises.question: Match the connectors to their purpose.
exercises.example_sentence: The results were poor; hence, the project was cancelled.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for formal flow: 'Suffice it to say, the results exceeded our expectations.'
exercises.answer: Suffice it to say, the results exceeded our expectations.
exercises.example_sentence: Suffice it to say, the results exceeded our expectations.
